strow.stentry:
Deploying a Docker Image
Add the variables from the <number>-Project-openrc.sh file that you have downloaded earlier to your terminal session.
On a Linux machine, navigate to the directory that contains the sh file and source the file, for example:source 12345678901234-Project-openrc.sh
When prompted, enter your OpenStack password.
On a Windows machine, add the variables from the sh file at the command prompt one by one, or add the commands to a batch file, for example:set OS_AUTH_URL=https://region-a.geo-1.identity.hpcloudsvc.com:35357/v2.0/ set OS_USERNAME=myUsername set OS_PASSWORD=myPassword123 set OS_TENANT_ID=12345678901234 set OS_TENANT_NAME=MyCluster set OS_REGION_NAME=region-a.geo-1 When you close your terminal session, your variables will be discarded. To prevent this, you can do the following:
On a Linux machine, add the variables to your ~/.bashrc file and run the source ~/.bashrc command.
On a Windows machine, click Control Panel System Advanced system settings Environment Variables and add the variables to your System variables.
Decompress the file into a convenient directory.
Navigate to the directory and copy the overrides.tfvars.sample file, for example to myVars.tfvars.
Add the necessary keys and credentials for your cluster to your tfvars file.For more information, see Terraform Variables.
Run the following command:terraform apply -var-file=<myVariables>.tfvarsYou may receive the error message Can not find requested image if the various settings of your sandbox environment are not configured consistently on US East or US West.To improve console output on Windows, add the -no-color flag to your command. For more information, see the Terraform documentation on Command: Apply.
Terraform creates the necessary security groups and instances, installs Docker, installs the Docker images required to run , and saves the state of your infrastructure to terraform.tfstate.At the end of the process, Terraform displays the URL of the core, formatted using the xip.io wildcard DNS, for example:api_endpoint = http://api.203.0.113.0.xip.ioYou will need this URL to use the Cloud Foundry CLI. You can also run the terraform show command to see detailed information about the core.If the cluster creation process fails, run the following command to clean up created resources before attempting to create a new cluster:terraform destroy -var-file=<myVariables>.tfvarsExploring the Core
After the Docker image is deployed as an instance on , you can view the instance and its security groups:
To view the instance, click Project Compute Instances .
To view the security group, click Project Computer Access and Security .
Ensure that the required security group is available, for example hcf-container-host.
